OK, So what? What time do you go to bed at night time? And what time do you get to sleep? OK, what about hobbies or exercise or anything else outside work? Do you do anything else outside work? And if is it ever got so bad that you've actually had to miss work? OK. And apart from work, are there any other situations which evoke quite extreme anxiety, like being in public places, social situations, public transport, anything like that? OK, before this, did you have any similar times in your life when you felt like this? OK. And what about your mood day-to-day? I mean, I can see that you're quite distressed by it, but do you ever get really down about this?  And when do you think you last felt yourself? And where do you, who do you live with at home? Who do you live with at home? And how much alcohol do you have in an average week, do you think?  OK. So how much would you, would you guess? OK. Have you have you talked to anyone, talk to any councillors, done any online, looked online at all anyways? OK. OK. And would you be happy to have someone to one therapy? OK. What we would suggest in the first instance is to to so you can self refer by the NHS for what we call like talking therapy, which type of behavioural therapy where they can really look at your situation, how you're reacting to the what was provoking the anxiety and what you can do to try and overcome that. So I can send you the link for that. In the meantime, it can be a bit of a wait. There are some online resources that are really helpful. So if you call the support line, you can arrange the to have the blood test done. OK. All right, take care. Sorry, wait over.
